title: Lesson B1-1 Assessment: Introduction to Polypersonal Verbs

questions.question: What does 'polypersonal' mean in the context of Georgian verbs?

options.text: Verbs that mark both subject AND object in a single word form
Verbs that are used in formal speech only

questions.explanation: Polypersonal verbs simultaneously mark both the subject and object in one verb form, which is a distinctive feature of Georgian grammar.

questions.question: Which verb form means 'I see'?
questions.explanation: ვხედავ [vkhedav] means 'I see.' The ვ- [v-] prefix marks first person singular subject.

questions.question: What tenses does Series I cover in Georgian?
questions.explanation: Series I covers both Present and Future tenses in Georgian. Context determines which time frame is intended.

questions.question: How many verb classes does Georgian have?
questions.explanation: Georgian verbs are organized into four classes (I-IV) based on their grammatical behavior: Transitive, Intransitive, Medial, and Indirect.

questions.question: Match the Series I verb forms to their correct translations:
questions.explanation: Remember: ვ- [v-] marks first person, -ს [-s] marks third person singular, and -ენ [-en] marks third person plural.

questions.question: What is the subject marker for third person singular in Series I?
questions.explanation: The suffix -ს [-s] marks third person singular (he/she/it) in Series I conjugation.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly demonstrates a Class I (Transitive) verb?
questions.explanation: Class I verbs are transitive verbs that take a direct object. 'I read the book' has a direct object (book), making it Class I. მე ვმუშაობ [me vmushaob] is Class II (intransitive).

questions.question: In the sentence: 'დღეს ვმუშაობ [dgh'es vmushaob],' what does the verb indicate?

options.text: Both present or future, depending on context

questions.explanation: დღეს [dgh'es] means 'today,' which indicates present tense. The same Series I verb form can mean present or future, but the context word 'today' clarifies it's present.
